title: My Essential AI Tools for Creativity and Productivity
excerpt: An overview of the AI tools that are revolutionizing my creative workflow.
content:
My Essential AI Tools for Creativity and Productivity

In today's digital landscape, I use various AI tools daily that help me be more creative, efficient, and organized. Here are the key tools that enhance my workflow.

My Personal AI Toolbox

Chat GPT (O3): My reliable assistant for research, complex questions, and mathematical calculations. Particularly valuable for brainstorming, problem-solving, and gathering information for new projects.

Manus: When tasks require advanced agent usage, I turn to Manus. It excels at detailed research and automating complex workflows through its ability to plan and execute multiple steps autonomously.

Windsurf: My go-to tool for "vibecoding.". It enables me to quickly turn creative ideas into functioning code, significantly accelerating the development of web applications and automation scripts.

Notion: Essential for note-taking and personal assistance. With AI integration, it helps me organize my thoughts, create project plans, and clearly document my creative ideas.

Gemini 2.5 Pro: For token-intensive tasks like summarizing long documents or analyzing large data sets, Gemini is my first choice. It processes complex content with remarkable accuracy.

Opus Clip: A lifesaver for automatic short video creation. It helps me optimize content for social media without spending hours on video editing.

Readwise: For reading and archiving articles, collecting inspirations, and summarizing important concepts. It helps me keep up with the latest developments in my areas of interest.

Zapier: The backbone of my automation. It connects all my various tools and platforms, allowing me to focus on creative tasks while routine operations run in the background.

AI as an Everyday Partner

These tools are not meant to replace human abilities, but to enhance them. They help me overcome administrative hurdles and have more time for what matters: creative thinking, strategic decisions, and personal interactions.

Especially with complex tasks, research, and overcoming mental blocks, these AI assistants are invaluable. They offer new perspectives and approaches that I might not have discovered on my own.

The Future of AI as a Creative Tool

While we're just scratching the surface of what AI can do in creative processes, I'm convinced that the true revolution is yet to come. The connection between human creativity and the analytical and generative capabilities of AI will open up entirely new forms of expression and ways of working.

For creatives in all fields, it's more important than ever to understand these tools and integrate them into their workflow to remain competitive and optimally implement their creative vision.

AI tools have fundamentally changed my way of working. They have not only increased my productivity but also opened up new creative paths that were previously unimaginable. The future of work lies in the harmonious collaboration between human intelligence and artificial systems.
author: Ole Oskar Heinrichs

title: Why Ableton Live Became My All‑In‑One Creative Hub
excerpt: After trying numerous DAWs, I've found Ableton Live to be the most intuitive and versatile solution for my creative workflow.
content:
I've tried more DAWs than I care to admit, but every time I return to Ableton. When one of my songwriting professors told me to "pick a single DAW and master it," I took that advice to heart.

I'd already bounced between Ableton for production and FL Studio for vocals, yet the more I compared them, the more obvious it became: Ableton just makes sense.

My Round‑Trip Journey

First: Ableton was the first DAW I ever opened. Opening a DAW for the first time is always overwhelming.

The detour: I switched to FL Studio for a while because every tutorial I watched they used it.

The homecoming: After wrestling with FL's endless ten‑click workflows, I ran back to Ableton and promised I'd stay. One DAW, one focus, no more split‑brain sessions.

1 · Three Clicks vs. Ten

In FL Studio I often need ten clicks to do what takes three clicks in Ableton. Browser on the left, devices at the bottom, shortcuts that actually shorten things—everything's right where I expect it.

The interface is so clean that I rarely think about how to do something; I just do it.

2 · Viable for Everything

Recording guitars? Easy. MIDI programming? A dream. Live performance? Rock‑solid. Mixing? Built‑in devices that actually sound good.

Ableton doesn't force me into "this DAW for that task." It's versatile enough that I trust it from the first spark of an idea to the final master.

4 · Templates & Customization

I keep a template for every scenario—writing sessions, vocal comping, live sets—and loading them takes seconds.

With custom key maps and color‑coded tracks, the software bends to my workflow instead of the other way around.

5 · Stock Devices, Zero "Schnickschnack"

Operator, Wavetable, Drum Rack, EQ Eight, Echo—these stock tools sound great and behave exactly as advertised.

I don't need three third‑party compressors when Glue gets it done. Less time auditioning plugins means more time finishing songs. (Not that I still splurge on plugins once in a while)

6 · New Features That Actually Matter

The AI‑powered sample library surfaces sounds that fit my project instead of burying me in options. The revamped MIDI tools make complex chord voicings effortless.

Every update feels like a quality‑of‑life boost, not bloatware.

Why I'm Committing to Mastery

Other DAWs each have a specialty—FL's beat making, Logic's bundled instruments, Pro Tools' editing—but they also have blind spots.

Ableton may not perfect every single feature, but it nails them all well enough that nothing feels compromised. By focusing on Live, I get depth and breadth, and that's the combination I need to grow from competent to expert.

Final Word

Ableton Live doesn't just help me make music; it removes the friction between inspiration and execution. The less I fight the software, the more I create.
author: Ole Oskar Heinrichs
